text:
VNT is quality journalism, and the people who work for @vicenews, past and present, are quality journalists. I’ll miss working with them. But I’m definitely going to keep watching & reading. 

If you’re not watching, you should be. Don’t sleep on @vicenews tonight. 10/10
author: ajjaffe

text: These pieces were shot & edited by a hugely talented team, and all of them were touched by many more hands in post-production to make them look and sound amazing. It takes a village. 9/
author: ajjaffe

text: & @tejarrett is not only one of my oldest friends, she’s also an incredible features producer. She & the fearless @ahylton26 team up for some of the most thought-provoking pieces, like this one about gangs in Chicago: 8/
author: ajjaffe

text: @EvanMcS is endlessly hilarious & his perspective on politics is unlike anybody else's in Washington — but he also does great features, like this one on how a transgender girl is coping with backlash from her town: 7/
author: ajjaffe

text: @wheelb has a knack for finding the most offbeat angle possible on a politics & policy story — like this one, where he & @EvanMcS went to rural Alaska to see why public radio’s so important outside of big cities: 6/
author: ajjaffe

text: @simonemperez consistently delivers greatness, no matter the assignment. She was the one behind our fantastic paparazzi piece, edited by the incredible @victoles: 5/
author: ajjaffe

text: Producer @bitofaninny is a politics nerd, but she also does incredible features, like this one we did on a rape survivor’s effort to get consent classes taught in schools: 4/
author: ajjaffe

text: In the DC office, our fearless leader is @Shawna, who does it all…including some of the sharpest political analysis around, like this piece on why this time a deal to avoid a shutdown is within sight: 3/
author: ajjaffe

text: Every day they make a small miracle happen by getting the show on the air — and there’s an amazing, talented team of reporters, producers, shooters and editors behind them, who work their asses off to make great TV. 2/
author: ajjaffe

text: Today was my last day at Vice. I’m excited for my next adventure covering politics in Iowa for the AP — but I’m so proud to have spent the last two years as part of the incredible team helmed by @Tyrangiel & @madhaeringer. 1/

text: Bureau of Prisons employees are worried that failure to pay their debts—because they're not receiving a paycheck—could give their employer reason to terminate them in the future. It's in the BOP's standards of conduct: https://www.bop.gov/policy/progstat/3420_011.pdf …

text: Eddie Canales, who's spent 30 years working as a corrections officer, told me a wall isn't "worth shit if I can't feed my family." They've been through shutdowns before, but say this one is different because there's no end in sight.

text: We spoke with Bureau of Prisons staffers—two who voted for Trump and two who didn't—about the shutdown. The guys who voted for Trump said he's lost their support because of how he's handled it.

text: Some corrections officers are taking on second jobs—driving uber, doing repair work on the side—to make sure they can make ends meet.

text: It’s part of China’s broader push to expand its reach in South America, to places other countries—including the US—have taken for granted. The NYT did a great piece on the base & China’s global ambitions:

text: ...and as big as this space base, about 40 miles away from Las Lajas, in the Patagonian desert. The cone on the right is a huge, rotating satellite; the tower on the left is part of the living quarters for the Chinese who run the facility.

text: This was the scene in parts of Onslow County today - the swift water rescue team sent these along from their welfare checks. County Manager David Cotton told me he believes full recovery could take two years. #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: I think he secretly likes being twitter famous
author: ajjaffe

text: My dad is happy I’m heading home
author: ajjaffe

text: Onslow County Manager David Cotton told me it could take as much as two years for the county to fully recover. More from the ground here in Jacksonville, NC. #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: While we spent the last 96h with the Onslow County Emergency Management team, @robferdman rode out the storm with a family in Lumberton. Our coverage of #HurricaneFlorence airs tonight on @vicenews on @HBO, 7:30pm.
author: ajjaffe

text: Many, many thanks to the Onslow County Emergency Operations Center team, which quite literally housed & fed the ⁦@vicenews⁩ crew on the ground in Jacksonville throughout the storm—all while responding to a flood of emergencies. Residents here are lucky to have them.
author: ajjaffe

text: ‘⁦@jaffesj⁩ is still not happy I’m here
author: ajjaffe

text: A little normalcy returning to Jacksonville, NC - Angry Ginger is up and running, serving beers, burgers & BLTs. Nothing on the TV but the pool tables are working just fine #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: The view from one of the military vehicles yesterday as we forded one of the flooded highways in Jacksonville #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: From yesterday - a swift water rescue team heads out to help a van caught in flash flooding up to its headlights on a highway in Jacksonville, NC #HurricaneFlorence People have been rescued, but much of this flooding remains.
author: ajjaffe

text: About 2.5h west of us, the scene is similar —>
author: ajjaffe

text: I’m told there were 150 people rescued yesterday in Onslow County — not including the many dogs & cats brought to shelters by first responders. Here, they load up military vehicles provided by Marines with residents & pets from flooded Richlands, NC #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: Rain’s stopped here in Jacksonville & the sun is out for the first time in days, but heavy flooding still remains
author: ajjaffe

text: If the president’s “fake news” refrain becomes his undoing...
author: ajjaffe

text: Stranded for a few hours b/c flooding made it impossible to leave the area, and first responders were out...responding. Many thanks to the lovely folks at the Richlands Volunteer Fire Dept for their hospitality & good cheer, in the middle of a long & difficult weekend
author: ajjaffe

text: Ugh save us some
author: ajjaffe

text: Meanwhile, @shaqbrewster and I are actually *working* out here in Jacksonville, NC. Tssk tssk Danny taking a Saturday off.
author: ajjaffe

text: Onslow County’s also getting Coast Guard support—4 helicopters have been out in the storm, with 6 expected by the end of the day. By about 2pm they had made 30 air rescues.
author: ajjaffe

text: A whole caravan of Marines are headed out to support Onslow County rescue efforts. They’re the only vehicles capable of getting through some of the highest waters here
author: ajjaffe

text: There are 25-30 people still waiting for rescue from flooding in the Richlands area—the Onslow County swift water rescue team is headed there now on high water vehicles provided by Marines from Camp Lejeune.
author: ajjaffe

text: We’re told the Coast Guard just sent in 3 helicopters to Onslow County to help rescue 25-30 people that are facing rising waters in the Richlands area. #HurricanceFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: From the ⁦@vicenews⁩ team on the ground here in NC & in NYC—our dispatch from #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: Flooding up to an emergency vehicle’s headlights here in Jacksonville NC #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: Looks like landline phones are all down in the Jacksonville, NC area. Appears 911 still works, but calls to Camp Lejeune, Jacksonville PD, Fire Dept, Mayor's Office & Emergency Management Office all register a busy signal
author: ajjaffe

text: When POTUS tweeted this, we knew of at least 4 deaths from #HurricaneFlorence. This AM, 7 total. Death tolls & counts rise as situation develops & officials get a clearer grasp on the situation. Raises Qs about how Trump is appraising hurricane damage here in NC.
author: ajjaffe

text: Yesterday around 3pm Onslow County had abt 100ppl in shelters—this morning around 6am it was 329 & rising. They’re scouting locations to open another shelter here but having trouble, since many of the schools they’d typically use are flooding. #HurricanceFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: The flooding is bad enough here that the rescuers need rescuing. Emergency vehicles getting swept away in the rising waters.
author: ajjaffe

text: Onslow County emergency response staffer leaves the building after spending more than 72h here dealing with #HurricaneFlorence. Most of the staff have been sleeping here since Weds/Thurs night.
author: ajjaffe

text: Well I'll keep an eye out I suppose
author: ajjaffe

text: This is a traumatizing thread and it almost makes me glad I’m stuck in a storm in North Carolina
author: ajjaffe

text: Here @ Onslow County Emergency Services, about 50m north of Wilmington, they’re expecting at least 2 more feet of water, and at 8AM winds were 90mph #HurricaneFlorence
author: ajjaffe

author: ajjaffe

author: ajjaffe

text: Don’t tell your dad when you’re going to cover a hurricane it will only make him anxious
author: ajjaffe

text: WCTI-TV, in New Bern, an hour north of us, evacuated their building because of a storm surge. This is what the channel looked like before our power cut. #HurricanceFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: I spoke too soon, we just lost power
author: ajjaffe

text: Just arrived in Jacksonville, NC, about an hour north of Wilmington. Here’s the view from our hotel lobby. Very high winds, rain, but no flooding. We’re in an area that’s lost quite a bit of power & lights are flickering but so far no loss. #HurricanceFlorence
author: ajjaffe

text: Cooper spoke to HUD Sec. Carson today about needing "flexibility" in tackling with housing issues b/c some residents are still dealing with Hurricane Matthew recovery
author: ajjaffe

text: Gov. Cooper says he's spoken to the President along with a number of Cabinet Secretaries—HHS, HUD, Commerce, DHS— "personally, to make sure we have that federal commitment that's going to be necessary to make sure we get the job done."
author: ajjaffe

text: Cooper: "Our greatest concern about this storm remains the same. The storm surge and massive flooding both are going to be extreme...Make no mistake — we’re on the wrong side of this thing. This storm will bring destruction to NC."
author: ajjaffe

text: NC Gov. Cooper: "I'm concerned because I've even heard some people say that North Carolina’s getting a break. Please hear my message: we cannot underestimate this storm."
author: ajjaffe

text: NC Gov. Cooper: “My message today: Don’t relax, don’t get complacent, stay on guard. This is a powerful storm that can kill.”

text:
On Election Day, officials had to deal with:
-A rumor one of the voting system vendors may have been compromised
-A former state employee complaining on FB the voting systems were hacked
-Flash mobs at polling places
-The governor trying to vote twice 
-Lots of other chaos

text: 4.5h into Election Day, the state’s voter data system went down for 5 minutes. When it went back up, there was a flood of voting - and long lines - at a bunch of polling places, which staff had to juggle

text: One surprise here in Fresno: 3 longtime Republican voters who were unhappy with Nunes & not sure if they’d support him this fall. Said they felt he had lost touch with the district, wasn’t accessible to constituents & was promoting himself more than focusing on local needs #CA22
author: ajjaffe

text: It’s a cycle - people don’t subscribe because they don’t feel the paper is providing enough local news coverage; profits go down; newspapers lay off reporters & can offer even less local news coverage
author: ajjaffe

text: And alt-weekly/Indy papers are dying off too...
author: ajjaffe

text: That said—every reporter we spoke to at the Fresno Bee said they know there’s a portion of the population that will never trust their reporting, and they’re basically resigned to that. They acknowledged more or less writing them off.
author: ajjaffe

text: But there doesn’t seem to be much the media can do to win these ppl back. It’s not about facts; nobody seemed to be able to explain how to evaluate fact vs. fiction. It’s about who they trust; Trump is still winning that battle here in Fresno.
author: ajjaffe

text: None of them think the president is lying. I had multiple people tell me the media simply does not tell the truth, and there wasn’t much the national media or paper here could do to win their trust. But nobody could clearly explain how they evaluated facts vs. Fake news.
author: ajjaffe

text: Fresno-area voters from both parties said they felt the print paper included too much generic & national wire coverage & not enough local news, and by the time they received it in the morning the news was already old.
author: ajjaffe

text: Most of the people we spoke to in the Fresno area said they felt their newspaper had been disappointing them for years—not just with biased reporting, but because the newspaper simply isn’t useful anymore, or worth the money.
author: ajjaffe

text: We’ve spoken to at least 20 Republicans in the Fresno area today, most of whom said they were sick of the media “tearing down” the president and that he (and Nunes) has the right to defend himself #CA22
author: ajjaffe

text: If Mueller releases report now w/out Trump intvu, Giuliani & co. have more fuel to call it partisan; if Mueller waits for subpoena fight to be decided in court, public patience with & interest in investigation continues to wane.
author: ajjaffe

text: When we spent days w/Cheri Bustos, who’s in charge of messaging to rural/red districts, she emphasized Dems need to talk policy/their “Better Deal” agenda. Seems that wasn’t selling
author: ajjaffe

text: Hello from the @FresnoBee, where we’re chatting with @MackenzieMays and the rest of the reporting team here about @DevinNunes’ attacks on the paper & what happens when “Fake News” goes local
